Climate aware ORSA
WHITEPAPER
FEBRUARY 2022
Climate-related risks are impacting many aspects of an insurers business. One of the tools
insurers use to assess the potential impacts of risks and investigate different optimization
Author
strategies is the Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA). While the regulatory capital

year risk measure) the ORSA is often broader, spanning governance and risk management

MOODY’S ANALYTICS CLIMATE AWARE ORSA 2Why now
In recent years the pressure on companies to manage climate-related risks and reduce their greenhouse gas emissions to net zero
has come from multiple stakeholders, for example:
» Climate change activists and net zero industry bodies recognize the weight insurers and pension funds have in the financial
sector.
» Customers have become more aware of their options and have more options and are making more informed financial
decisions. They consider more than just value for money when choosing an insurer or pension company and a product.
Ultimately, they are voting with their feet.
» Analysts and investors have always considered how effective managing is at seizing opportunities and managing risks for
profit. Climate-related risks are potentially significant.
» Rating agencies are incorporating the management of climate-related risks along with wider ESG considerations into their
credit rating as it impacts the ability of an insurer to repay debts.
» Regulators are concerned with stability of the market and the protection of customers and want evidence that the risks and
opportunities are being appropriately identified and managed.
MOODY’S ANALYTICS CLIMATE AWARE ORSA 3Why ORSA
Although a risk assessment is carried out to calculate the regulatory capital requirement, the ORSA is much broader. It spans all
risks, not just those mitigated by capital and broader risk management activities. It also looks beyond the downside risks to
consider the opportunities (upside risks) and actions required to realize them. The insurer chooses the assumptions and
methodologies most appropriate to their business, although in many cases the ORSA is reviewed by the regulator so the choice is
not unrestricted. Typically, the exercise is carried out annually although many of the components are carried out more frequently.
The ORSA can require several iterations as different combinations of scenarios (external factors) and strategies (insurer-driven
actions) are investigated. The output of the exercise is typically a report presented to the board, and after it is approved, shared
with the regulator. The report may contain and/ or refer to some or all the following items:
» Description of key risk policies (including risk appetites, limits, and other metrics)
» Description of key risk processes (includes roles, responsibilities, and key output)
» Evidence the policies and processes are working effectively
» Methodology, key assumptions, and parameters for calculations (including sensitivities)
» Reconciliation of key metrics to other published reporting bases
» Rationale for and narrative of scenarios considered
» Projected results under various scenarios (can be broken down by region, portfolio, and so on)
» Mitigating actions and management responses (currently available and future alternatives)
» Next steps
The report is used to determine follow-up investigations, actions, and strategies that can impact all areas of the business such as
pricing, product features, reinsurance, capital requirements, investment choices, and others.
Incorporating climate change risk into the ORSA is much more than just updating a single report. As can be seen from the ORSA
contents in the bullet point list above, the ORSA relies on many other policies and processes that will need to be reviewed for
climate change impacts.
Risk policies and processes
Most insurers are already managing their risks with risk appetites, risk limits, defined roles, responsibilities, key metrics and so on.
The policies and processes typically cover the main market risks, demographic risks, and operational risks to which the insurer is
exposed. Many insurers have already started reviewing and updating these for climate risks. For example, physical risks can impact
the incidence of demographic risks so any key risk indicators may need to change to work effectively as early warning signals.
Changes may be required to the investment risk policy to allow the insurer to make changes to the investment strategy for
climate-priced assets. Some insurers have also created a separate climate-change risk policy. After these policies and processes are
in place, they need to be regularly tested to assess whether they are working effectively and what improvements are required.
Results generation
Both regulators and industry bodies have issued guidance on financial disclosures, for example the Taskforce for Climate-related
Financial Disclosures (TCFD)1. These include testing the resilience of your strategy under different scenarios (including 2oC or
lower), disclosing the metrics used to assess climate-related risks and the performance against targets. While these relate to public
disclosures the principles can be applied to private results and expanded further in the ORSA. Results generation is discussed more
in the next section.
1 Recommendations from the TCFD, TCFD, June 2017
MOODY’S ANALYTICS CLIMATE AWARE ORSA 4Mitigating actions and management responses
Many insurers are being proactive in managing climate-related risks and have already increased their access to mitigation options
and management actions. For example, some insurers have already reviewed their investment strategy and made changes –
disinvesting from some dirty asset classes and increasing investment in clean asset classes. Some insurers have already changed
product terms, included new options or developed new climate-friendly products. The financial implications of these actions are
investigated before the actions are approved. Some insurers are preparing for the materialization of specific transition risks by
investigating potential responses.
What is happening
Most risks involve uncertainty, however the speed of changes, the compound nature of physical risks, the irregular nature of
transition risks and the interactions between the two exacerbate the uncertainty over the impact of climate-related risks.
Incorporating climate change risks into the ORSA results is a good first place to start investigating the impacts, mitigations, and
actions. There are many challenges to address in order to produce the ORSA results, for example:
» Which scenarios – which combinations of physical and transition risks, similar or extreme scenarios, which scenario is the
‘baseline’, how many scenarios.
» How to translate scenarios into model inputs – economic and non-economic variables, correlations and consistency.
» How to model over long time horizon – whether to include new business or run-off, how to roll over assets, deterministic or
stochastic on stochastic valuation.
» What level of granularity – is data available for entity or sector level parameters, annual or x-yearly time steps, portfolio or
company level results.
» Which outputs to produce – whether to model both assets and liabilities, capital measures, key risk indicators, key
profit/performance measures, fund-specific measures, climate-specific measures.
Climate-related ORSA results challenges
MOODY’S ANALYTICS CLIMATE AWARE ORSA 5Some insurers have already started making changes to try to address some of these challenges and have been encouraged by
regulators. For example, European Insurance and Occupational Pension Authority (EIOPA) released its guidance to supervisors on
the use of climate change scenarios in ORSA2 which included some guidance on the following:
» Definition of climate change risk
» Integration of climate change risks in ORSA in the short and long term
» Materiality assessment of climate change risks
» Range of climate change risk scenarios
» Modeling transition and physical impacts at granular level
» Lower precision and frequency of long-term scenario analyses
» Evolution of climate change risks analyses
» Supervisory reporting and consistent disclosure
» Reporting requirements
» Monitoring by EIOPA
The changes to the ORSA for the inclusion of climate change risks aim to help insurers to make more informed decisions across
the business. However, there are many challenges to incorporate climate-related risks into the ORSA to output results and metrics
that are useful for investigating alternative strategies, mitigating actions and decision-making. Insurers are using combinations of
in-house expertise, industry data, and industry/consultancy models to start to overcome these challenges. Best practice will
emerge as insurers, regulators, and other stakeholders learn from their ORSA experiences.
